In Julia, Write a function `clean_column` that cleans a column name (`col`) by lowercasing it, stripping any leading or trailing whitespaces, and replacing any spaces and hyphens with an underscore, eg, "My Column" becomes "my_column".

You can achieve this using the built-in `replace`, `lowercase` functions in Julia. Here is a function that does what you asked for:

```julia
function clean_column(col)
    return replace(lowercase(col), r"[ -]+" => "_")
end
```

Here's how this function works: 

- `replace(lowercase(col), r"[ -]+" => "_")` 

This line will replace all spaces and hyphens in the column name with underscores, and it converts all characters to lower case. The `r"[ -]+"` part of the code is a regular expression that matches any number of space or hyphen characters (denoted by `[ -]`), and `"_"` is what we replace those matched characters with (denoted by `=> "_"`).
